Award.AwardTitle: REU Site in Chemistry at the University of Rochester
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) at the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site led by Professor Thomas R. Krugh at the University of Rochester. REU students will participate in a 10 week summer program. The primary focus for REU students will be full-time hands-on scientific research as a member of an established research team. Each participant will have a specific research problem, a specific faculty adviser, and a specific mentor to provide day-to-day advice. A weekly REU Group Meeting provides a forum for participants to report their research to each other early in the summer in the form of an oral presentation, and again at the end of the program in a poster presentation and final written report. Participants will learn from each other and about other areas of chemistry in the oral and poster presentations. REU students will participate in a variety of activities, including sessions on careers and a visit the Laboratory for Laser Energetics, and will have a mini-course on entrepreneurship in chemistry. Recruitment of students will give emphasis to the participation of underrepresented minorities, women, and lower division students.

Undergraduates will complete an independent research project, gain a perspective on life as a graduate student in chemistry, participate in the search toward discovery, gain in-depth knowledge in their research area, and be exposed to research in other areas through oral presentations and a poster session. REU students gain a sense of their abilities to succeed in a Ph.D. program and in a career in chemistry through real participation in the research endeavor. Students leave with a poster that some will choose to display in their home department, along with PowerPoint slides for an oral presentation. The Group Meetings also will be used to discuss graduate education, scientific careers, responsible conduct of research and scientific ethics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Rochester Chemistry REU site received funding to support eight students per year in a ten week REU program in Chemistry.  The primary focus of REU students involved full-time hands-on scientific research as a member of an established research team.  Each participant had a specific research problem with a faculty adviser along with a mentor to provide day-to-day advice.  A weekly REU Group Meeting provided a forum for participants to report their research to each other early in the summer in the form of an oral presentation, and again at the end of the program in a poster presentation and final written report. Participants learned from their faculty advisor, their research group mentor, and from each other, and about other areas of chemistry, in the oral and poster presentations and in a variety of social activities. The REU program included sessions on careers, a visit to the University of Rochester Laboratory for Laser Energetics, and a session on entrepreneurship in chemistry. 

   Intellectual Merit.  Undergraduates completed an independent research project, gained an appreciation of life as a graduate student in chemistry, participated in the excitement of discovery, gained in-depth knowledge in their research area, and were exposed to research in other areas through oral presentations and a poster session. The weekly Group Meetings included discussion of graduate education and careers in science.  Graduate student mentors experienced a valuable learning experience in leadership.  Annual assessment documented the impact of the REU program on students in terms of their plans to pursue advanced education. 

   Broader Impacts.  REU students completed the program with enthusiasm for scientific research, and gained a sense of confidence of their abilities to succeed in a Ph.D. program, thus increasing the likelihood they will pursue a career in chemistry.  Students leave with a poster that some will choose to display in their home department, along with PowerPoint slides for an oral presentation.  All undergraduate student researchers are incorporated into an inclusive Rochester REU site in Chemistry, significantly enhancing the impact of NSF funds.  During the 2015-2018 grant cycle a total of 101 undergraduates participated in the Rochester NSF REU site in Chemistry, which included 30 students from other institutions as NSF REU Participants.  During the 2015-2018 grant cycle the Rochester REU site included 14 underrepresented minority students as NSF REU Participants.
